Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ion-Trap "Integrated Circuit" Technology for Quantum Information Processor

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit

This proposal presents a career development plan for integrating research and education on the topic of hardware system development for trapped ion quantum information processors
(QIPs). Toward this goal, critical research activities for system-level design and enabling
technology development are proposed. System design and optimization bounded by performance
requirements and available technology should be an on-going process in this effort. It is anticipated that a MOEM system that delivers the large number of precisely tailored laser beams required for qubit manipulation will be a critical missing technology component. Experimental development of functionally integrated MOEMS technology optimized for this purpose is proposed as the main activity of the proposal.
Broader Impacts.

The technology platform for integrated MOEMS will find a variety of exciting
applications in other areas of science and engineering research, including integrated atomic clocks, inertial sensors, optical communication elements and integrated optical sensors. A network of researchers with diverse expertise established will be valuable source of future innovation and research initiatives.

The educational component is an attempt to introduce a new paradigm for engineering education at all levels aimed at stimulating creativity, and ultimately will enhance the career prospects of the engineering students. The undergraduate curriculum development effort will concentrate on developing project-based laboratory experience at early stages of engineering education. Fundamental topics, like quantum information, will motivate the students while the projects will be managed to expose students to non-technical topics like teamwork and leadership on top of technical contents. The graduate courses will emphasize engineering principles for integrating cutting-edge technology into a practical system design.

The PI and the institution (Duke University) has successful track record of educating female and
minority engineers, and will continue to expand research and educational opportunities for them.

These activities will stimulate collaboration between physicists and engineers on this front: historically, such collaboration played a critical role in every juncture of successful application of new physical discoveries. Forming a collaborative effort among experts with various technology components to realize a QIP in the long run will also be an important element critical to the success of the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
If one is allowed to utilize the counter-intuitive properties allowed by quantum physics, it is shown that certain computational task can be performed in a very efficient way. An important example is cracking of secret codes used to protect national security or electronic commerce traffic. Some of these codes would take longer than the age of the universe to break using all computers available to mankind today, but if a large enough quantum computer can be constructed, it could be broken in a much shorter time.

Individual atomic ions, where an electron has been stripped off from an atom, can be trapped in an ultra-high vacuum chamber using oscillating electric fields. The internal atomic levels behave like a well-isolated quantum system, and can be utilized to represent a quantum bit (or qubit) of information. Experimentalists have used laser beams to prepare, manipulate and detect the quantum states of an atomic ion, which provides a promising physical system from which quantum computers can be constructed.

However, a typical trapped ion experiment looks nothing like a computer: a compact system that can represent a very large number of information bits. We recognize the lack of integration technology, analogous to the integrated circuits (IC) technology that led to modern computers and information revolution, is the main hurdle towards realizing a practical quantum computer. In this research project, we explored a scalable system design for constructing a trapped ion quantum computer and new technology improvements in micro-optoelectromechanical systems (MOEMS) critical in realizing such a system design. Furthermore, we recognized the inherent multidisciplinary nature of such an endeavor, and seek broad collaboration among researchers with unique technical and theoretical backgrounds to construct a common vision of the system realization.

Through the research program, the PI and collaborators have invented a scalable architectural platform for constructing trapped ion quantum computer. It is based on a large number of small computing registers connected through photonic channels, leveraging existing optical MEMS technologies. The PI’s group pioneered development of small micro-mirror technology carefully adapted for the needs in quantum computing, and demonstrated its applicability in atomic physics experiments. The research effort supported by this program has led to the launch of a number of nation-wide collaborative research initiatives aimed at demonstrating scalable quantum computer prototypes.

The PI has also contributed in establishing quantum information processing and MEMS research at Duke University. The PI developed a highly popular quantum information science course at Duke, and introduced a MEMS course that involves hands-on experience of MEMS device design, fabrication and test. These course have been integrated with the photonics education initiative at Duke University. The research effort has trained several Ph.D. and Master’s students and provided research opportunities for several undergraduate students in the Electrical and Computer Engineering department at Duke University.
